Specific Details: In February 2016 we purchased a shell and core property at unit 5 Balbriggan Retail Park. We sought letters of support for our group and for our application for Change of Use from our local representatives.
DPOs Lobbied: James Reilly|Minister|Department of Children and Youth Affairs::Brendan Ryan|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Clare Daly|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Darragh O'Brien|Senator|Seanad::Gráinne Maguire|Councillor|Fingal County Council::Tony Murphy|Councillor|Fingal County Council
Subject Matter: In February 2016 we purchased a shell and core property at unit 5 Balbriggan Retail Park. We sought letters of support for our group and for our application for Change of Use from our local representatives.
Intended Results: We hoped to secure approval for our application for change of use of our newly purchased property.::We hoped to get information on any grants we might be eligible to apply for and to secure support for same.
Lobbying Activities: We were established in 1998 and have grown from 15 families to over 250 families impacting on over 750 people. We have known for some time that the only way for our 'Club’ Remember Us to grow was to get a permanent ‘Home’ of our own. Through fundraising  we purchased Unit 5 Balbriggan Retail Park. The property is a shell and core which will allow us to fit it out and tailor it to our needs. As it was originally built as a retail unit we needed to apply for change of use so as part of our application we included letters of support from our local representatives who know the value of the service we offer to the community.|Email|2-5::The property we purchased is shell and core and as part of our plans we intend to have a sports hall for our members. Minister Ryan had assisted us to apply for a grant towards the cost of the flooring in our sports hall and we sought his assistance in chasing it up|Email|6-10

Specific Details: requirement for a masterplan to be prepared by the Council and be formally approved in advance of planning permission applications being considered
DPOs Lobbied: Tom O'Leary|Councillor|Fingal County Council::Brian Dennehy|Councillor|Fingal County Council::Gráinne Maguire|Councillor|Fingal County Council::Barry Martin|Councillor|Fingal County Council::Tony Murphy|Councillor|Fingal County Council::Malachy Quinn|Councillor|Fingal County Council::David O'Connor|Councillor|Fingal County Council::Eoghan Murphy|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Darragh O'Brien|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: requirement for a masterplan to be prepared by the Council and be formally approved in advance of planning permission applications being considered
Intended Results: modification of the requirement to allow a masterplan that was prepared by the landowners themselves in conjunction with Council planners to be approved
Lobbying Activities: The absence of an approved masterplan means that lands that were zoned residential in the Fingal Development Plan adopted back in 2011 cannot get planning approval for houses to be built on them. This was highlighted to the local elected representatives and some key members of Dail Eireann. The landowners consulted with the planners in FCC on the preparation of a masterplan for the zoned lands and submitted this masterplan in mid 2017.  They sought to have this masterplan approved by the Council, enabling planning applications to progress. This was the procedure that was followed by the Council in the past.|Email|2-5

Dyspraxia/DCD Ireland proposes to improve the provision of support to the person and family affected by Dyspraxia/DCD.  This will be achieved b
Intended Results: As indicated above, our organisation, through its support of families and professionals concerned with children with Dyspraxia/DCD, provides services that are ancillary to services provided by the HSE and relieves pressure on those services.  HSE personnel currently re-direct callers with queries regarding Dyspraxia/DCD to the Association.  Increased staffing will greatly enhance our capacity to liaise with, support and educate HSE staff on Dyspraxia/DCD. Our work with individuals and families w
Lobbying Activities:
Leinster House meeting regarding our funding application  and where we stand re same .Dyspraxia/DCD Ireland is an organisation in Ireland that provides a flexible, person-centred approach to its service users. Many of our users avail of our services in the local area when they require it, often at critical junctures in their life such as an initial diagnosis, starting secondary school or employment. We encourage our service users to remain active in the community and seek to give them the skills to advocate on their own behalf throughout their lifetime.  Dyspraxia/ DCD Ireland service users access our services in a way which meets their needs whether that is calling the helpline, attending a workshop or a local support group. Due to the highly complex manner in which Dyspraxia/ DCD present itself all support is offered on a person-centred basis.

Lobbyist Name: Society of the Irish Motor Industry
Specific Details: Operation of the Covid Wage Subsidy Scheme, and concerns that it could unintentionally exclude some Motor Industry employees who should qualify for the scheme.
DPOs Lobbied: Darragh O'Brien|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Niall Cody|Chairman|The Office of the Revenue Commissioners
Subject Matter: Operation of the Covid Wage Subsidy Scheme, and concerns that it could unintentionally exclude some Motor Industry employees who should qualify for the scheme.
Intended Results: The initial operation of the Covid Susbsidy did not take account of the seasonality of earnings in some sectors. In particular employees in receipt of commisions or bonuses in Jan/Feb which either don't recur at the same level in subsequent months or are non-recurring appear to be excluded from the Scheme. This operation of the Scheme does not reflect (as per the legislation) “net weekly emoluments that would otherwise have been payable”. This anomaly needs addressing.
Lobbying Activities: Phone call with Darragh O'Brien TD (April 9th)|Phone call|1::Email to Darragh O'Brien TD (April 14th)|Email|1::Phone call with Chairman of the Revenue Commissioners (April 14th)|Phone call|1

Specific Details: The Minister for Housing, Local Government and Heritage visited Anew's Supported Temporary Accommodation Service on 4th December (an outdoor visit with social distancing, in line with Covid-19 guidelines which were in place at the time) to celebrate our service by planting a Cherry Blossom Tree.  We asked for a meeting with him to discuss the need to extend our service, to illustrate the value for money, effectiveness and high quality of service and discuss challenges for the service.
DPOs Lobbied: Darragh O'Brien|Minister|Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage
Subject Matter: The Minister for Housing, Local Government and Heritage visited Anew's Supported Temporary Accommodation Service on 4th December (an outdoor visit with social distancing, in line with Covid-19 guidelines which were in place at the time) to celebrate our service by planting a Cherry Blossom Tree.  We asked for a meeting with him to discuss the need to extend our service, to illustrate the value for money, effectiveness and high quality of service and discuss challenges for the service.
Intended Results: Maintain existing funding and explore funding opportunities to extend our services. Illustrate the effectiveness and necessity of intensive supports and early intervention alongside accommodation services.  Show the value for money that this provides long term for Anew's services users i.e. pregnant women, new mothers, their babies and extended family who are experiencing homelessness.
Lobbying Activities: The Minister for Housing, Local Government and Heritage visited Anew's Supported Temporary Accommodation Service in Swords on 4th Dec 2020, which is located in his constituency. The purpose was to celebrate the service and plant a Cherry Blossom tree. We asked for a further meeting with the Minister to discuss our service as detailed above.|Event / Reception|1

Specific Details: Anew met with Minister Daragh O'Brien, Reps from DRHE and the Department of Housing on 18th Feb 2021 (on-line). Anew highlighted that we have a consistent waiting list of about 10 homeless pregnant women for 4 beds. These women have complex support needs, so other homeless services are not appropriate. The Minister noted that the DRHE always welcome new proposals from services and he suggested that Anew submit a proposal for extra capacity, with good evidence for the need.
DPOs Lobbied: Darragh O'Brien|Minister|Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage
Subject Matter: Anew met with Minister Daragh O'Brien, Reps from DRHE and the Department of Housing on 18th Feb 2021 (on-line). Anew highlighted that we have a consistent waiting list of about 10 homeless pregnant women for 4 beds. These women have complex support needs, so other homeless services are not appropriate. The Minister noted that the DRHE always welcome new proposals from services and he suggested that Anew submit a proposal for extra capacity, with good evidence for the need.
Intended Results: We are hoping to secure additional beds and funding to provide support for the extra capacity based on the model of service in our supported temporary accommmodation for homeless pregnant women. The service has excellent outcomes and is successful in exiting 80% of residents from homelessness within 6 months. Additional capacity would mean we could exit even more women and their babies from homelessness.
Lobbying Activities: Meeting on 1 Feb as detailed above.|Virtual Meeting|1::Emails with the Minister's office to organise the meeting.|Email|2-5

Specific Details: Residential Tenancies Act
DPOs Lobbied: Darragh O'Brien|Minister|Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage
Subject Matter: Residential Tenancies Act
Intended Results: The introduction of a mechanism for landlords trapped by RPZ's with rent substantially below market rent to allow them to bring their rent to a sustainable level.::The Harmonised Indices of Consumer Prices is unfit for purpose, it does not reflect the cost of the provision of accommodation.  It is important that an index utilised reflects the actual cost of the accommodation, including mortgage interest, insurance, plumbing, carpentry, painting, cleaning, and gardening costs.::Rental Properties in Rent Pressure Zones when sold are being lost to the market.  A simple measure to assist this would be to lift the RPZ restriction when sold, allowing a new purchaser to obtain market rent.::Advance consultation with the providers of accommodation so that the potential affects of legislative changes and unintended consequences  can be understood in advance of changes to legislation.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Stephen Faughnan Chairman Irish Property Owners' Association

Specific Details: Sophia as part of the Homeless Network submitted a letter to a number of ministers drawing their attention to the role of front line staff in homeless services during the pandemic and that they should be included in the covid recognition payment.
DPOs Lobbied: Leo Varadkar|Minister|Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment::Michael McGrath|Minister|Department of Public Expenditure and Reform::Darragh O'Brien|Minister|Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage::Mary Hayes|Director of Services or Equivalent|Dublin City Council
Subject Matter: Sophia as part of the Homeless Network submitted a letter to a number of ministers drawing their attention to the role of front line staff in homeless services during the pandemic and that they should be included in the covid recognition payment.
Intended Results: We hoped  that our staff (including nurses, project workers, care workers, cleaners, catering, and other auxiliary staff) who worked with residents, clients and services users on a face-toface basis during the pandemic should have their contributions recognised for inclusion in this Covid Recognition Payment Scheme
Lobbying Activities:
The Dublin Homeless Network comprises 16 organisations that provide services for homeless and socially excluded households and communities within Dublin and in some cases nationally. The Network meets to share information and to assist in the coordination and delivery of services and policy responses. Its members play a vital part in Dublin and nationally in supporting some of the most marginalised households by providing a full spectrum of services in the prevention of homelessness, providing supported temporary and emergency accommodation and providing long term supported housing. The Dublin Homeless Network nominate onto the governance structures of the DRHE. Sophia is one of the members of this network. 

The letter submitted highlighted the commitment of our staff in supporting the most vulnerable in our society, despite the risk to themselves, throughout the pandemic and that they should be recognized along with other frontline workers.|Letter|1
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Sophia is a member of the Dublin Homeless Network which submitted a lobbying letter on behalf of all members.

Specific Details: Requesting whether the minister had ever received a costs benefit analysis (more recent than 2012) for the greater Dublin Drainage project, particularly in relation to his request as an opposition minister in 2019. And if the answer was no, if he would in his capacity of Minister for Housing  overseeing ERVIA and Irish Water if he would request an updated CBA in 2022.
DPOs Lobbied: Darragh O'Brien|Minister|Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage
Subject Matter: Requesting whether the minister had ever received a costs benefit analysis (more recent than 2012) for the greater Dublin Drainage project, particularly in relation to his request as an opposition minister in 2019. And if the answer was no, if he would in his capacity of Minister for Housing  overseeing ERVIA and Irish Water if he would request an updated CBA in 2022.
Intended Results: An up to date figure of costs as the most recent CBA was from 2012 ten years ago.
Lobbying Activities:
I asked the Minister if he had ever received a reply to his request for a CBA while in opposition as per the following; 
https://www.darraghobrien.ie/news/govt-are-yet-to-produce-a-cost-benefit-analysis-of-greater-dublin-drainage-project

If he had not I asked that in his new capacity as Minister for DHLG if he would request the following information in the below-suggested format.


I suggested that the question is split as follows for clarity:
1. How much money has been spent to date on the project up to year end 2021.
2. How much the project is currently projected to cost based on Construction Index and land value prices (CPO) Dec 2021. 
3. What is the uplift from the amount previously declared to the CRU for the Irish Waters revenue control programme for the Greater Dublin Drainage Project.

I would also be grateful if it can be confirmed if the project has received any direct funding from the EU or has had EU funding diverted to it from department disbursements.|Email|2-5

Lobbyist Name: Property Owners Association of Ireland Limited (IPOA)
Specific Details: Residential Tenancies Act 2004 as Amended  -  The system for annual registration is not fit for purpose.  Landlords are trying to comply with their obligation to register but system is not functioning  The old system is gone and the new system has problems with data linking, registration, termination of previous tenancies.  It is impossible to get through by phone and landlords are not getting responses to their emails.  Late registration fees will be incurred as a result of RTB system issues.
DPOs Lobbied: Darragh O'Brien|Minister|Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage
Subject Matter: Residential Tenancies Act 2004 as Amended  -  The system for annual registration is not fit for purpose.  Landlords are trying to comply with their obligation to register but system is not functioning  The old system is gone and the new system has problems with data linking, registration, termination of previous tenancies.  It is impossible to get through by phone and landlords are not getting responses to their emails.  Late registration fees will be incurred as a result of RTB system issues.
Intended Results: Deferment of introduction of penalties until such time as new registration system is working in an efficient manner and backlog has been cleared..

Specific Details: Wild Bird Declarations
DPOs Lobbied: Darragh O'Brien|Minister|Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage::Ciara Shaughnessy|Special Adviser|Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage::Kevin Dillon|Special Adviser|Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage
Subject Matter: Wild Bird Declarations
Intended Results: To acknowledge the extension of three months to 31 July 2022 to the existing General and Air Safety Wild Bird Declarations which allows for the completion of the review of submissions received as part of the public consultation process; the receipt of legal advice; and other internal discussions in relation to the species included on the Declaration.::To highlight that it is critically important that the derogation is extended beyond the 31 July 2022. July, August and September are extremely important months for the harvesting of grains, fruits and brassicas crops.::To highlight that while control of birds is necessary throughout the year, it is quite obvious that the damage caused by pigeons and corvids is very critical throughout the months of June, July and August in particular.::To seek a meeting with Minister Darragh O'Brien Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage, to discuss this further.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Tim Cullinan, IFA President; Damian McDonald, IFA Director General; Elaine Farrell, IFA Director of Governance & Oireachtas Engagement; Willie Shortall, IFA

Specific Details: FLAC sent a joint letter and briefing note to the Minister regarding a proposal to publish legislation amending eligibility for housing
DPOs Lobbied: Darragh O'Brien|Minister|Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage
Subject Matter: FLAC sent a joint letter and briefing note to the Minister regarding a proposal to publish legislation amending eligibility for housing
Intended Results: The joint letter and briefing note sought confirmation that any change to the eligibility criteria for access to social housing supports will proceed by way of primary legislation and only on foot of a robust consultation process. It noted that the organisations would welcome an opportunity to meet the Minister to discuss the matters raised.
Lobbying Activities:
FLAC sent a joint letter and briefing note (along with Mercy Law Resource Centre, Crosscare, the Irish Refugee Council, Community Law and Mediation and the Immigrant Council of Ireland) to Darragh O'Brien TD, Minister for Housing, Local Government and Heritage. The letter issued by email and post on 21 December 2022. The letter related to the published response of the Minister to a parliamentary question in which he proposed to “bring forward legislation early in the new year regarding eligibility of non-nationals for social housing, including provision for legal residence as an eligibility criterion in any assessment for social housing support”. The briefing note set out a number of preliminary concerns in relation to this proposal. 
The joint letter and briefing note sought confirmation that any change to the eligibility criteria for access to social housing supports will proceed by way of primary legislation and only on foot of a robust consultation process.|Email|1

Specific Details: Data Centres are on the increase abd their recent growth in their electricity cosumption is frightening. This puts pressure on the achievement of our climate targets. We need to reduce energy demand
DPOs Lobbied: Simon Coveney|Minister|Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment::Eamon Ryan|Minister|Department of Environment, Climate and Communications::Darragh O'Brien|Minister|Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage
Subject Matter: Data Centres are on the increase abd their recent growth in their electricity cosumption is frightening. This puts pressure on the achievement of our climate targets. We need to reduce energy demand
Intended Results: We need to prevent Ireland getting locked into using fossil fuels for years to come. Instead we need to double our efforts to reduce polluting emissions. Furthermore data being oused in these centres is also used to track and sell us stuff that we mightn't otherwises buy. Excess consumption of products we don't really need is a huge contribution to the climate crisis and the broader ecological crisis

Subject Matter: Standard Funding Threshold (STF)

Specific Details: We wrote a letter detailing our views on what should be included in any review of the 1988 Housing Act
DPOs Lobbied: Darragh O'Brien|Minister|Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage
Subject Matter: We wrote a letter detailing our views on what should be included in any review of the 1988 Housing Act
Intended Results: Including among other points, that any reform of the Act must be predicated on the State recognising and vindicating all persons right to adequate housing with the State also recognising and guaranteeing in its laws the right of every person to appropriate shelter; and that that any amendments promote equality, prevent discrimination and protect the human rights of all homeless individuals and families by fully implementing the Public Sector Human Rights and Equality Duty.

Specific Details: On the 18 April 2024 Ciara McGrath of Crosscare co-signed a letter sent by post and by email to Darragh O'Brien T.D. Minister for Housing, Local Government and Heritage. The letter was about the General Scheme of the Housing (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 2024 and raised concern at the proposals to introduce “right to reside” and “habitual residence” conditions for access to social housing supports as set out in Part 2 of the General Scheme.
DPOs Lobbied: Darragh O'Brien|Minister|Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage
Subject Matter: On the 18 April 2024 Ciara McGrath of Crosscare co-signed a letter sent by post and by email to Darragh O'Brien T.D. Minister for Housing, Local Government and Heritage. The letter was about the General Scheme of the Housing (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 2024 and raised concern at the proposals to introduce “right to reside” and “habitual residence” conditions for access to social housing supports as set out in Part 2 of the General Scheme.
Intended Results: We wanted to make the Minister aware that the proposed amendments to the General Scheme were unduly harsh in respect of our migrant client group. Prior to the advancements of any amendments, a comprehensive consultation process be undertaken to include the views of the Irish Human Rights and Equality Commission and that the General Scheme would be subject to a comprehensive process of pre-legislative scrutiny involving the participation of stakeholders.

Specific Details: Planning & Development Bill 2023
DPOs Lobbied: Darragh O'Brien|Minister|Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage::Kevin Dillon|Special Adviser|Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage
Subject Matter: Planning & Development Bill 2023
Intended Results: To acknowledge the progression of the Planning and Development Bill 2023 over the last number of months and the revision of the previous Planning and Development Act 2000, that we hope will make planning procedures more streamlined and easier for farm families to invest in the development of their enterprises.::To emphasise that it is imperative for farm families that planning applications are streamlined, effective, and not open to obstruction by false and unfounded claims by members of the public or organisations which have no sufficient interest in the progression of a planning procedure.::To highlight that it has never been more important for farmers to have the ability to invest in their enterprises to advance the sustainability and profitability of their businesses in the face of an increasingly uncertain policy environment. This is especially important in the context of increasing slurry/nutrient storage on farms to improve nutrient balances, which IFA has communicated consistently over the past number of months.::To welcome the more comprehensive definition of sufficient interest in Section 271 of the proposed Bill for unincorporated bodies and hopes this will prevent unfounded legal claims being pursued by individuals or organisations whose only goal is to prevent the development of farm businesses. To also welcome the tighter time frame for judicial proceedings to be conducted under the new Bill and the more comprehensive nature of this section of Bill in its entirety.::To voice concerns  remaining within the proposed Bill which IFA seeks clarity on moving forward. Under Section 271 (3) of the proposed Bill, it remains a possibility for individuals to take judicial proceedings against planning applications regardless of whether they are directly or indirectly materially affected on the basis that the claimant has contributed relevant submissions in a material form prior to this.::This has the potential to undermine the firmer nature of the definition of sufficient interest for Organisations and Unincorporated bodies referenced above and thus has the potential to not resolve the issue of serial objection which has consistently disrupted planning procedures in rural areas for a number of years.::To note the previous definition in the Draft Planning and Development Bill 2022 in Section 249 (C) ;::(c) the applicant has a sufficient interest in the ground and for these purposes—::(i) an applicant shall not be regarded as having a sufficient interest for the purpose of this section unless that applicant is or may be directly or indirectly materially affected by the matters to which the application relates.::(ii) a sufficient interest shall not be limited to an interest in land or a financial interest.::To highlight the loss of this definition from the Planning and Development Bill as it provides a far clearer and more comprehensive definition of sufficient interest which may have helped prevent serial objectors from taking unfounded claims against planning applications that disrupt on farm development.::To show concern at the establishment of an Environmental Legal Assistance Fund under Section 280 of the proposed Bill. It is fair to presume that the safeguard of financial assistance in the face of a lost claim will only further promote the amount of unfounded environmental claims brought forward for judicial review.::This mechanism is disproportional and has the potential to hamper any progress made elsewhere in the Bill on making planning procedures faster and simpler for the development of farms and rural areas.::To highlight increased concern at the length of time it is taking to secure planning for environment structures such as slurry/nutrient storage tanks or anaerobic digestion facilities. IFA believes that there should be an enabling clause in the legislation to allow local authorities to fast-track approvals for environmental infrastructure which are in line with Government policy.::To request that the concerns outlined above will be considered in their entirety prior to enacting the final legislation. Only those who have a direct interest in planning applications should have the ability to contest the legitimacy of an application, consistent with the definition outlined in the Draft Bill from 2022.::To also seek clarity on how the proposed Environmental Legal Assistance Mechanism will function and what type of claims may qualify for remuneration under this provision.::To highlight the vexatious nature of planning appeals that are disrupting farmers' plans to upgrade their farms and make them more efficient.::To emphasise that it is absolutely vital that the new Planning and Development Bill ensures farmer planning applications are not open to obstruction by false and unfounded claims by individuals or organisations who have no sufficient interest in the progression of a planning application.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Francie Gorman IFA President, John Murphy IFA Environment & Rural Affairs Chair, Pat Carroll IFA South Tipperary Chair

Highlighting Clonmel's Ustekinumab biosimilar with potential savings of at least 55%. Expedite these savings by endorsing biosimilars ahead of the BVB process.::Request that our representatives in Europe, encourage the European Council to delay the vote on the recast UWWTD until a full impact assessment can be done, one that accurately estimates the true costs to patients and Europe’s/Ireland’s generic medicine supply. If the vote proceeds, then to request that the implementation of the directive locally in Ireland is reassessed.

- Meeting with Stephen Donnelly, Minister of Health.
- Location, Ministers office at Government Buildings.
- To expedite the usage of biosimilars such as Ustekinumab in order to deliver significant savings to the overall health budget.|Meeting|1
